user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked: We switched to Onshape in 2021 from Solidworks and intend to stay with them indefinitely, pending a reversal of their educational support. The primary advantage is enhanced student accessibility. From basic devices like school-issue iPads to advanced CAD workstations, nearly anyone can now use our robot CAD software, whereas Solidworks' requirement for loading robot models is beyond what most families or individuals can afford. Since the switch, we've observed a dramatic increase in student prototyping and robot design involvement. What used to be an 80% mentorship ratio has flipped to 100% student involvement, making it easier for students to build robots as they primarily rely on CAD systems developed by mentors.

posts.name: Joe Johnson
posts.cooked:
An older laptop, which I purchased for $150 a year ago, can run Onshape with the latest updates without any hassle. This ease of use significantly reduces friction, helping more students adopt CAD tools.

Using Onshape offers several advantages. Teams can access the latest CAD files without managing file versions, avoiding issues like checking in/out, downloads, conflict resolution, and unauthorized edits. These features simplify collaboration and improve workflow efficiency.

While Onshape isn't perfect, it remains the top choice for FIRST teams among various CAD options. My professional experience includes using multiple packages, confirming Onshape's value despite its shortcomings.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
While I'm not a CAD expert, I must consider costs when deciding which software to use. Free access to FIRST Robotics Competition materials via a Solidworks subscription is ideal, especially if it fits my budget.

Some schools already have access to CAD tools, including Solidworks, and integrating it into robotics classes makes sense. However, our school needs cost-effective solutions. While MKCAD is beneficial, I'm unsure about Solidworks' availability for it.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.cooked: Another great advantage is that every person on the CAD team is always looking at the latest CAD and isnâ€™t blocked by having to check in/check out files, download the latest versions, resolve possible conflicts, or risk overwriting their work. It is another barrier to driving CAD that is vastly reduced by using Onshape. Not just the CAD team, itâ€™s really useful for me as a programmer to be able to look at the latest version of the CAD, and for the people machining parts to just go to [link] and see what they need to do.

posts.name: Sam

posts.name: Ian Bae
posts.cooked:
for newcomers to cad and design including collaboration onshape is highly recommended. its resources are extensive and collaboration features are top-tier.  

i personally prefer solidworks over onshape and siemens nx due to their advanced features combining cad and cam. while siemens nx is excellent it may not be as comprehensive. solidworks is often the better choice for those aiming to work in industries utilizing cad software.  

both programs offer free student versions though solidworks is specifically tailored for frc competitions and comes as part of a package.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: The one thing I appreciate about Onshape...regardless of the platform (pc, mac, linux) files just cross over on one system. SW you have to have different "systems" to do this.

posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked: The text discusses the comparison between traditional CAD systems like Autodesk Inventor and newer web-based systems like OnShape, particularly focusing on their application in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) teams. The author reflects on their experience transitioning to Autodesk Fusion during the COVID-19 pandemic, highlighting its benefits such as remote collaboration and ease of use across multiple devices. Despite initial challenges with OnShape's workflow and community support, the author emphasizes the significant time savings fusion provides. They acknowledge concerns about OnShape's long-term relevance beyond educational settings, noting a lack of widespread adoption of its advanced features within the FRC community. Overall, the author values the efficiency of web-based tools like OnShape, despite personal adaptation difficulties, and expresses reservations about their sustained utility post-graduation.

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked: OnShape appears to be valuable despite limited personal experience. Legacy data remains a significant barrier for transitioning to new software. While companies like Solidworks may claim high reliability, OnShapeâ€™s strategy of offering free seats to educational users seems aimed at enhancing its market presence.
